reviewText:
TL:DR? See Conclusion
INTRODUCTION:Max Payne 2: Fall of Max Payne is the sequel to the critically acclaimed and award winning 2001 game, Max Payne. Max Payne 2 is a Third-Person action shooter developed by Remedy Entertainment which was acquired by Rockstar Games whose notable works include the popular Grand Theft Auto (GTA) franchise.

Once again the player steps into the shoes of Max Payne, a New York City Detective who, after the events of the first game, went on a downward spiral both in career and personal life, struggling with the death of his family and his newly formed Pain Killer addiction (the direct result of the pain killers taken by the player in the first game to regenerate lost health). While Max is investigating a series of murders and assassinations, Max encounters Mona Sax, a textbook femme fatale who was presumed dead from the first game. Follow Max and Mona's adventure through New York City and discover a conspiracy behind a Mob War between two rival Mafia groups and a deadly team of hitmen called 'The Cleaners' in this film noir love story.

PROS:+ Significant and highly noticeable improvements on the graphics, animation and texture quality from the first title
+ Better sounds, voice acting and sound track
+ Improvements on the innovative Bullet Time game mechanic
+ Great locations and level design which goes well with the better graphical fidelity
+ Graphic Novel style cutscenes are back and with better delivery
+ Expanded weapon variety
+ Mission variety
+ Challenging Difficulty levels (the game provides a good challenge on any difficulty setting)
+ Adaptive difficulty if the player is on Easy Mode. (AI gets toned down and pain killers heal more if the player dies too much on Easy Mode.)
+ Magnificent story that surpasses even the first game
+ World is ALIVE and more immersive.

CONS:- VERY Short (I personally completed it within 5-6 hours)

OTHER NOTE:- Replayability: - Linear storytelling is FINE, its a good way to tell a narrative story in a directed pace but Linearity does sacrifice replayability at degree because, after finishing the story, there is little reason to play through it a second time around. Like a good action movie, it's best to be played again after some time has passed. (Copy Pasted from my Max Payne 1 Review)

CONCLUSION:I rarely call something a 'MASTERPIECE' but after playing through the whole game, twice (once on my Xbox back in 2005, once again on my PC 2013), and sitting here writing this review, I cannot find any more CONs aside from the short story. Contrast this to the PROS I listed, I can easily say we have an almost perfect action game. Max Payne 2 blends perfectly the immersive storytelling of a good action movie, and the dynamic adrenaline pumping gameplay of a video game.

MUST BUY and HIGHLY RECOMMENDED for both new and old fans a like. I do, however, not recommend you buy this game solo but instead, BUY the MAX PAYNE BUNDLE which includes the Original Max Payne and Max Payne 2. At $15, this is a game worth your time and money.

reviewText:
Max Payne 2: The Fall of Max Payne is a direct sequel to Remedy Entertainment's critically acclaimed 2001 third-person shooter Max Payne and picks up after the events of its predecessor. The game could be best described as noir-style love story, in contrast to the first that was more of a film noir revenge tale.

NYPD detective Max Payne is once again the primary protagonist, although a few very interesting segments sees you play as his love interest, Mona Sax. Max Payne 2 borrows a lot from the original and there are enough hints and references to the previous game which helps keep the narrative interesting and fresh for old-timers.

Max Payne 2 is, in many ways, a huge improvement over Max Payne 1. Gone is that constipated look  replaced instead with full 3-D modeled faces. The game also sees an immense graphical upgrade with excellent usage of the Havok 2.0 physics engine. Game characters are more detailed while environment objects, including enemies, tumble and fall very realistically.

Gameplay is largely the same with a few refinements to combat. Bullet Time sees an upgrade allowing you to dodge bullets and reload quickly, with a cool whirling animation to go alongside it. This results in a higher body count but also makes gun-play segments a whole lot less challenging. Level designs are, once again, brilliant with mission locales ranging from warehouses, mansions, hospitals and clubs to constructions sites. And the enemy AI is, on a whole, pretty decent although in a few instances they end up killing themselves with their own grenade.

The plot is riveting with almost non-stop action throughout. The storyline unfolds in much the same fashion as the original. The usage of graphic novel comics complete with melodramatic over-the-top dialogue sucks you into the game's environment. If anything, the writing is more polished this time around with lots of witty and philosophical quotes thrown into the mix. The story focuses too much upon the love-story angle though which tends to get a bit jarring towards the end. In comparison, the original Max Payne's story, although slightly rough around the edges, was more dark, grittier and compelling than its sequel.

For a game that is over twelve years old, Max Payne 2 still holds remarkably well today. It overshadows the original in many aspects while also introducing a few cool mechanics of its own. Simplified mechanics make for interesting combat segments making Max Payne 2 one of the very best third-person shooters ever made.

Taking a step forward deep into the chaotic endless black desert of insanity.

Max Payne 2 eventhough it stands on common ground it really has many differences from its predecessor.
Something that made the hard core fans of the first game not like it too much at first.

Where do I begin? Max Payne 2 The Fall of Max Payne is a fantastic experience from start to end. Especially if you have the Cinema 2.0 Mod which I used in my playthrough of the game. (The Mod really enhances the experience).

Storywise this game is interesting, compelling, and tells a dark tale of Max Payne. Max lost his wife and kid in the previous game and in this one he loses even more (I'm not going to spoil it). The story is told not through cutscenes like in modern games but through something like out of a Graphic Novel. The game is told through 3 Acts all having about 6 to 8 Chapters.

Gameplay wise this game has it perfected. It's an old school shooter. It's fun, fast, and can be difficult at times (Except in the last chapter where there is practically painkillers around every damn corner) and Bullet Time is a fantastic feature which allows you to slow down time and shoot in slow-mo just like in an action movie (You can even dodge and jump forward in Slow-Mo). There is also a lot of guns (Even a Minigun) but you lose them in certian chapters and have to collect them again. You do all of this in Third Person which makes it even cooler seen Max dodge bullets and shoot punks.

Graphics still hold up today. This game looks great and very little loading screens (only when you get to a new chapter) and character models looks great. It's not any Next-Gen Graphics but it's great vanilla and looks even better with Graphical Mods you can download.

Do I recommend this game? Yes. It's a great game.

Should you buy it right now or wait for a sale? Buy it now if you have the cash unless you're really tight on money then wait for a sale.

Max Payne 2: The Fall of Max Payne improves on everything which made the first game great and even surpasses it in some aspects. The gameplay isn't as awkward as before thanks to improved hitboxes and bullet trajectories, a sense of realism surrounds the game because of physics simulations like ragdoll effects, and the identity of the series has been given a new facelift thanks to higher production values. Overall, an excellent action game that's worthy of the Max Payne name and fans will be happy with this installment. However, if you're new to the series or have only played the Rockstar-made entry, you won't get as much from this game and everything will just look like a confusing mess. Max Payne 2 is a story-centric game and it builds on what fans and players of the first game already knows. This time around, the true intentions of the first game's major players are shown and reveals a new side to them, making them more believable rather than being a one-sided cliche of a character. The story focuses on Max after the events of the first title as he reflects on his past choices and how he copes up with the decisions that he's made. I highly suggest that new players play the first game or watch a recap video because without knowledge of the characters' background and the events leading up to this game, the story becomes much less impactful and you won't get much out of it because of its focus on the cast rather than plot.

1. Better voice actors than the first game and their performances are consistent except for some select moments.

reviewText:
Max Payne 2 The Fall of Max Payne is one of those games that people hate and love. On the one hand you have the multitudes who proclaim that it's noir style is completely groundbreaking and that the storytelling stands in a league of it's own. On the other hand you have the many who say that it's nothing more than hype and that at it's core Max Payne 2 is nothing more than an average shooter enticing the wannabe artsy gamers with a pseudo-deep story and pretty cinematic. You can never tell who's right in an argument like this, both sides will provide equal parts well-thought counterpoints and nonsensical fanatical rantings.

Me, I really liked it. Sure the story is not as great as some proclaim but it's not the giant pile of lice infested feces that others call it. And yeah it's not 1930's French movie either but lets be honest, whether you like those kind of movies or not they'd never work as a game, the pacing is completely different.

What saves the game for me is the simple fact that the gameplay is nice and solid. The shooting is fast and meaty and the slow motion gimmick that the original Max Payne brought forth to the masses still works well enough that it doesn't bother me as much as it does in other games. Now there is a mechanic that got overused in later games.

There is a reason Max Payne is a name many gamers know. Beyond the story, the pretentious artsy cut scenes and all the posturing is some good and solid gameplay, and that's hard to ignore.

One of the best 3rd person games to have emerged out of the 2000s.  The plot, acting, characters, voice acting and gameplay mechanics are amazing to play even a decade later.

The flim noir feel to this game coupled with the hammy lines and gritty New York scene make the plot memorable and enjoyable. The landscapes, sounds, soundtrack, layout and even odd and slightly macabre portraits of the cut outs in the game make for an overally gloomy, moody and atmospheric game.

The bullet-time mechanics make this a pleasure to play as you hammer away with your twin deagles in bullet-time mode.

What's also really enjoyable are the game's idiosyncrasies: the Lords and Ladies television show that everyone watches with its overly hammy and campy acting; the strung out junkies and hookers who decide to join you only to last several minutes; or the old ladies who toss you a spare shotgun from their living room closet.

The soundtrack is absolutely beautiful and haunting with that repeating cello and accompanying orchestra.

The first Max Payne introduced the gamer to bullet-time mechanics along with an equally gritty plot copuled with Max's foray into his drug-addled dreamscapes while looking for his family's killers.

In the sequel, the graphics have been updated along with a continuation of the plot. I love what Remedy has done with both games.

With the third Max Payne, you are granted access to way better graphics, thanks to Rockstar, but frankly the plot paled in comparison with the previous two releases.

They don't make games like these anymore...

10/10

reviewText:
The awaited sequel to the blockbuster Max Payne has arrived, and I´m happy to report that it packs with it a ton of fun and hefty improvements which do a great job of fixing the original´s missteps.

Taking place 2 years after the events of the first game, Max Payne 2 places you right in the middle of the action, and it´s your job to reconstruct the events that led to where you are at the beginning of the adventure. It´s a clever storytelling tactic, and provides an excuse for Max to bust out his witty one-liners and noirish remarks which are dotted throught the entire six-hour campaign, even if they do get a little stale at parts. Twists and turns lurk around every corner, making this is a story you     won´t want to put down until you see it through.

Gameplay hasn´t been drastically improved, which isn´t a bad thing if you were a fan of the original´s bullet-time setpieces and deadly shootouts, but some aspects could have been changed up a bit. One thing I noticed was a heavier use of dream sequences, which are there to provide a breath from the action and push the story forward, but ultimately only serve as boring, linear sections with little to no fun to be had at all. Perspective is also played with, as the focus sometimes shifts from Max to another character I won´t name so as not to spoil it. These chapters are very cleverly intersected with the    protagonist´s own path, and provide a different angle on some key events in the story.

An aspect of this sequel which has received a major overhaul is definitely the audiovisual department. The voice acting is once again top-notch, and the graphics have been redesigned to give Max and the supporting characters a more realistic feel, even though the thugs' faces do tend to repeat themselves far too often for their own good. reviewText:
Max Payne 2 succeeds where it's predecessor did, telling a grim story through a comic-style setting. Once again, we see the dank world through the eyes of Max, being all too similar to this array of black and white, we are greeted with once again, New York. This game is grim, gruesome and most definietly dirty. And that's where Max Payne 2 shines, it's noir style story telling, it's emotional engagement with us as players, but most of all reach the titular character Max Payne to us on a personal level. It's hard to talk about how good the story is, without telling you the story of the first one (Although it's not mandatory to know the story of the first game) so avoiding spoilers in this review is hard to avoid, but rest assured, I will not spill any today.

Technically, this game is beautiful for it's time. Being ported around to multiple consoles, it's safe to say it's more powerful on the PC, and for good reason, it's developed by 3D realms co-insiding with Rockstar (Who went on to make Max Payne 3). The game play is smooth, the combat is clean, and the graphics are astonishing (In relation to it's time). There a few minor bugs here and there, especially on newer systems, since this game is not catered around for 64-Bit OS, or windows 7 at all (But they are various patches for that, I'd go and look at ancmilons patch guide on the Steam Forums).

The games major flaw is that it is far too similar to the first game, in terms of gameplay. I felt like I was just playing a B-Grade rip off of the original Max Payne. Fine, the game has been updated, the graphics are alot better, and the game is cleaner, but I didn't feel like I was doing anything new. It felt like it had a linear structure where I would go shoot some guys, and do the same again in differently designed room, and that's another point, the game was more linear than the original. There is not as much imaginiative level design to mess around the levels and explore, like in the Original. Although it sounds like i'm nit picking, this did reduce some points for me on a gamer level.

In conclusion, this game is a perfect sequel (Minus the repetiveness) and it follows on from the original story, in that all too similar dirty disgusting way, but unlike the original this has no replay value.

I played this back when it was first released but couldn't remember much about it so I decided to replay it.  It still holds up surprisingly well for being an older game.  The gunplay feels good (with better hit detection than the original Max Payne), the graphics are improved, and it seems to take itself a little more seriously by dropping all the goofy cartoon faces that Max Payne would make in the original (there's even an audio clip in the game where they kind of make fun of themselves for doing that).

The same old comic-style noir cut scenes are still here and as good as ever.  The story seemed a little less interesting this time and was more about Max chasing Mona Sax around and shooting up all kinds of baddies in the process.  There's a tag team section where Mona covers Max with a sniper rifle while he traverses a construction yard that is probably the pinnacle of the game's ingenuity.  The All Ghillied Up" mission in Call of Duty 4 gets a lot of praise for this idea but Max Payne 2 really thought of it first even if they didn't execute it quite as stylistically.

Lots of interesting locales though and the way you defeat the final boss was a means of thinking outside the box before it was cool to make games that think outside the box."

The Fall of Max Payne is one of those games that has pitch perfect writing. Sam Lake is a god amongst video game writers. What it comes down to is Max's inner monologues that subdue the player into escaping reality and entering the stark world of Max Payne.

Taking place two years after the events of the first masterpiece, Max Payne has been reinstated into the NYPD and is on the case of a group of hitmen that dress up as a cleaning crew. Max follows their trail while uncovering a conspiracy involving the Inner Circle, corrupt politicians, and dirty cops. Mona Sax reemerges early in the game, surviving her apparent death after getting shot in the head in the first one. She's on the run from the police but works with Max as they have similar goals.

The fall of Max Payne is that he falls in love with Mona Sax, he can't bring himself to turn her in or fight her; which makes the game a film noir love story (as stated on the iconic cover art).

The gameplay is very similar to the first one, why fix something that isn't broken, right? But the graphics are substantially better, Max's face doesn't look like a distorted Sam Lake and the models are certainly more polyganyl. The nightmare scenes are easier but still kinda crazy. And the music, the music is SO good. I would at times just pause the game and let the music play in the menu while getting some water or pop.

Outstanding

reviewText:
A thrilling conclusion to the events set up in Max Payne, Max Payne 2: The Fall of Max Payne is a rollercoaster ride of intrigue and murder. Sam Lake is a god of videogame writing, and it shows here as plot twists and betrayals abound and leave you wondering if it ever really was black and white.

The gunplay is stellar, but special note must be given to the bullet-time and shootdodge mechanics of MP2. In MP1, you could only slow down time when you dodged, which was a good but flawed mechanic. In MP2, you can use bullettime without dodging (though shootdodge remains a viable option) and every kill you make while in the slowed timescale refills your bullettime meter a small function. If you're quick and skillful, you can keep it up for a long time.

Overall, I'd recommend this game if you're a fan of noir, good storytelling, great gunplay and/or the first game.
10/10 Bullets

I rate the game Max Payne 2 2.5/5. OK. Well, not really ok. Actually it's kind of crappy.

Max Payne is a DRAMA QUEEN. Sure a lot of bad stuff happens to him and he has difficult situations to survive. However, what Max Payne goes through is as nothing when compared to what the average character has to go through during the course of any given Fallout game and you don't hear them whining about it so continuously. Look at what happens to Adam Jensen in Deus Ex: Human Revolution. Sure he complains but he does so nowhere near as much as Max Payne does. Remember all the crap that happened to Gordon Freeman from the Half Life games? Max Payne wouldn't have survived any of it because he would have been too busy feeling sorry for himself, wrapped up in his own melodrama. Sometimes Max Payne's attitude is funny but more often it just gets annoying.

This game's overdone, hard-boiled graphic novel style spoofs the original Max Payne's style except that game didn't even need spoofing. To make matters worse, the story feels disjointed and haphazardly slapped together. By today's standards the graphics have not aged well either as many of the environments now seem a little bland. The Lords and Lady's fake TV show is nice to see though and wandering around the police station was fun also. Overall though this third-person perspective action game is too linear and its plot is, to be frank, boring. The AI is good though (except for their terrible tendency to accidentally kill themselves with their own grenades). The ending feels a bit abrupt as well. The controls are good and the few bugs which occur are not too serious. The sound is excellent but only the menu theme song is any good and its merely a re-orchestrated version of the main theme from the first game. This game really should allow you to make choices which actually affect the plot (which would have made it much more fun and replayable) instead of forcing us to listen to the main character whine incessantly about how he doesn't have any choice and wax philosophical about moral-intellectual stuff of which he, and the game's developers and writers for that matter, clearly have absolutely no understanding. Worst of all (or perhaps best of all if you're sick of hearing Max Payne moan and groan) is that this is a very short game.

In my opinion, this is the best Max Payne game of the series, and it holds up surprisingly well given its age. Released alongside titles such as Call of Duty, Beyond Good and Evil, and Knights of the Old Republic, Max Payne 2 suffered the same issue as Psychonauts: a great game with great reviews, although nobody bought it.

The gameplay and gun mechanics are only really comparable to the original Max Payne (another great game that has aged well), except they're much tighter and more refined. The infamous Bullet Time ability works quite well here, and the shoot-dodging mechanic is almost perfected. The weapons all work fairly well, although the pistols and shotguns become a little too situational to be practical at the end of the game.

The story itself is fairly cut and dry, although the Noir comicbook style of storytelling gives the game it's real charm. Unlike the first Max Payne, the comicbook segments are intercut with cutscenes which serve only to enhance the overall experience. The gameplay has enough variety to remain fairly fresh through its runtime, including pseudo-escort missions which don't actually suck.

The biggest criticism this game received was its short length, and, too be fair, that's not too far off the mark. In comparison to the original game, this one is certainly shorter, although this has the added benefit of substantial pacing. The environments are varied enough to be quite distinct (an attribute many modern games can't compare to), and the comparatively shorter length helps make this game an easy pill to swallow.

To anyone interested in the Max Payne series (and, if you like artistic games, well crafted single player storytelling, or fine-tuned slow-mo gun battles you should be), this is the crown jewel, although this game can be best appreciated after a playthrough of the original game for context and a better understanding of how this game's engine improved significantly in two years. The third installment, Max Payne 3, is certainly fun in its own right as well, although, with so many little things changed, altered, and tweaked, it simply doesn't give as good of an appreciation of the Max Payne franchise that this game can provide.

In my opinion, this is the best Max Payne game of the series, and it holds up surprisingly well given its age. Released alongside titles such as Call of Duty, Beyond Good and Evil, and Knights of the Old Republic, Max Payne 2 suffered the same issue as Psychonauts: a great game with great reviews, although nobody bought it.

The gameplay and gun mechanics are only really comparable to the original Max Payne (another great game that has aged well), except they're much tighter and more refined. The infamous Bullet Time ability works quite well here, and the shoot-dodging mechanic is almost perfected. The weapons all work fairly well, although the pistols and shotguns become a little too situational to be practical at the end of the game.

The story itself is fairly cut and dry, although the Noir comicbook style of storytelling gives the game it's real charm. Unlike the first Max Payne, the comicbook segments are intercut with cutscenes which serve only to enhance the overall experience. The gameplay has enough variety to remain fairly fresh through its runtime, including pseudo-escort missions which don't actually suck.

The biggest criticism this game received was its short length, and, too be fair, that's not too far off the mark. In comparison to the original game, this one is certainly shorter, although this has the added benefit of substantial pacing. The environments are varied enough to be quite distinct (an attribute many modern games can't compare to), and the comparatively shorter length helps make this game an easy pill to swallow.

To anyone interested in the Max Payne series (and, if you like artistic games, well crafted single player storytelling, or fine-tuned slow-mo gun battles you should be), this is the crown jewel, although this game can be best appreciated after a playthrough of the original game for context and a better understanding of how this game's engine improved significantly in two years. The third installment, Max Payne 3, is certainly fun in its own right as well, although, with so many little things changed, altered, and tweaked, it simply doesn't give as good of an appreciation of the Max Payne franchise that this game can provide.

Max Payne 2 is a third-person action game that follows the events of Max Payne 1. It depicts a broken Max seeking redemption and he gets this through the game's other main character, a femme fatale known as Mona Sax.

Story: The game is basically a tragic love story between Max Payne and Mona Sax. Over the course of the game, Mona Sax is constantly on the run (for reasons you will find out in the game) and Max Payne, now an NYPD cop must pursue her. The more Max encounters Mona, the more he becomes infatuated with her and this creates an interesting dynamic between them. The story is well-told and interesting but not as poetic and dark as the original Max Payne.

Graphics: I can't say much about the graphics given that it came out more than 10 years ago (in 2003). What I can say that the visuals are still servicable and okay for today's standards and I would imagine that the graphics at the time were ground-breaking. Not so much nowadays.

Gameplay: The movement, gunplay and overall responsiveness in MP2 is much improved over Max Payne 1. Now you can equip an item like a grenade to another button, instead of needing to switch to it. Bullet time is back and it feels as good as ever. It is a lot of fun to activate Bullet Time and take out 3 to 4 enemies , and this really makes you feel like a badass. There is much less frustration to the controls this time round.

Overall, Max Payne 2 is a great action game that I believe has stood the test of time and is still better than some action games of today.

Just two years after the first Max Payne (2001) was released, Remedy came up with their second creation of the series, Max Payne 2 (2003). This time they developed a game which had a whole lot of better graphics, upgraded game mechanics, more interesting level design, a bunch of new guns and an enhanced level of voice acting as well as an enhancend level of enemy AI.

Anyhow, like it's predecessor, Max Payne 2 is also quite a fast-paced game. The guns introduced in the game have a good feel on them and while bullet time or shoot dodge is being used at the same time, it will double the enjoyment. Also, the enemies are not able to take ridiculous amount of bullets before they die anymore, which is a huge improvement on its own over the first Max Payne game. The gradually slowing bullet time is an awesome invention as it is easier for the player to handle big amount of opponents at the same time. The controllabilty of Max's moves is still going strong, the level of voice acting is great and because there is some improvements on the enemy AI, Max Payne 2 is a very enjoyable game at its best.

Now, not only the game mechanics has been proven to be better in Max Payne 2 than they are in Max Payne 1, but also the graphics have taken a big leap forward. Overall the environmental texturing have gotten to a higher level. Max can see his own reflection and the faces seen in the game are more natural than they used to be in the previous Max Payne game. The cars are a bit more than just boxes on the wheels and the whole level design is much more interesting.

Despite all the enhancements, the game is still all about running and shooting with no considerable variation between the firefights you encounter. The overall amount of usable guns is still quite low and the game will not last too long, as an average person who is playing the game through for the first time can beat the game in about 5 hours. Additional game modes seem to be quite useless to try as there is nothing to achieve by playing them. Also the original dark and gritty story has been swapped to a new and lame one, which is all about Max losing another loved one while also being betrayed by someone thought to be a friend of his. The dreams Max is experiencing while the story goes on have lost a big part of their original meaning as a source of dark and twisted feelings.

After all there is a huge amount of improvements in Max Payne 2, even though the run and shoot part leaves still much to be desired along with some other downsides seen in the game. Throughout the game you can find some easter eggs, and the mods made for this game can offer you a lot of additional fun. To this date I have beaten Max Payne 2 six times: three times before I had it on Steam and three times after that, with every given difficulty option. Because the game is quite short, I ended up spending only about 30 hours by playing it and could still give it a go. In other words I don't regret the time I have spent playing on this game. If you liked the predecessor of Max Payne 2, without a doubt you will fall in love with this one. The quality has been guaranteed, even though some things mentioned above could have been made better.

The music, the comic-dequences, the action of Max Payne 2 is much smoother and this makes the game flow so much better, but the plot is more confused and less impressive than Max Payne ones. Like its predecessor, and in some ways even more so, Max Payne 2 is just a remarkable production, and what it lacks in length or volume it more than makes up for in quality and density.

Max Payne 2 is a triumph in third-person shooters, building strongly upon the foundation built by it's predecessor. It makes no attempt to alter the gameplay, and didn't need to- the first game's action was solid, as was its atmosphere and music, both back in full force here (including a Poets of the Fall song) But it does expand Max's story in surprising directions. A mysterious assassin, thought dead. Old friends become new enemies. The machinations of powerful men, dwelling in shadow. Over the course of the game, Mona Sax is constantly on the run (for reasons you will find out in the game) and Max Payne, now an NYPD cop must pursue her. The more Max encounters Mona, the more he becomes infatuated with her and this creates an interesting dynamic between them. The story is well-told and interesting but not as poetic and dark as the original Max Payne.

Graphics: I can't say much about the graphics given that it came out more than 10 years ago (in 2003). What I can say that the visuals are still servicable and okay for today's standards and I would imagine that the graphics at the time were ground-breaking. Not so much nowadays.

Gameplay: The movement, gunplay and overall responsiveness in MP2 is much improved over Max Payne 1. Now you can equip an item like a grenade to another button, instead of needing to switch to it. Bullet time is back and it feels as good as ever. It is a lot of fun to activate Bullet Time and take out 3 to 4 enemies , and this really makes you feel like a badass. There is much less frustration to the controls this time round.

Overall, Max Payne 2 is a great action game that I believe has stood the test of time and is still better than some action games of today.

In my opinion this game is in most aspects an improvement over the original. But be warned: Steam version is as bad as Max Payne 1. If you have an OS that is newer than Windows XP, you will need to find and install some fixes for the game to even run, and then some more to fix the sounds issues and give it proper widescreen support.

After you get it up and running properly, expect the following:

- This game is much, much easier than the original Max Payne. Probably not too easy, but at least you will suffer much less cheap deaths, especially instant ones. Aiming is still hindered by forced vSync, but feels significantly more fluid than in previous game. There are harder modes for more challenge, but you need to beat it on default difficulty first.

- Combat feels less luck-based and more dependent on player's actual skill. Enemies, however, are not as mobile as in MP1, but still move around quite a bit. Weapons are rebalanced and are more diverse and shooting feels, for a lack of better term, just better. However, in most situations the player is stocked with enormous amount of weapons and ammo, which is nice from the variety perspective, but it also means that there is only a handful of instances where ammo conservation is a thing. The boss battle is also much more interesting.

- Physics are improved and expanded. There is semi-decent ragdoll in place now, and there's a lot of reactive clutter all over the levels, which adds quite a bit to the spectacle, especially when there are explosions going off. Speaking of spectacle - it looks just phenomenal for its age. Only human models are somewhat sub-par, but still huge improvement over the original.

- There is a metric ton of side content - TV shows, conversations, environmental storytelling, and thankfully you can skip it all very easily.

- The tone is entirely different now. MP1 was gritty, its humor was dark. MP2 is still a blood-soaked tragedy, but much lighter and cheesier, shifting from noir to alsmot being kitsch. It is both serious and deconstructive at the same time, hard-hitting the player with tangible drama, and then outright mocking events that predated the sequel - just watch a couple of 'episodes' of ♥♥♥♥ Justice on MP2's TVs. MP1 was suffering of both character and player, and MP2 leaves the pain to Payne(see what I did there?). But despite being somewhat bipolar, it delivers the 'feels' when it has the intent to do so.

- Bullet time is revamped. It regenerates now and is easier to use. Whether you'll like it or not is up to a personal preference.

If you enjoy story-rich third-person shooters this is one of the better ones. Buy it and play it. Just maybe try to buy it elsewhere first.

Just two years after the first Max Payne (2001) was released, Remedy came up with their second creation of the series, Max Payne 2 (2003). This time they developed a game which had a whole lot of better graphics, upgraded game mechanics, more interesting level design, a bunch of new guns and an enhanced level of voice acting as well as an enhancend level of enemy AI.

Anyhow, like it's predecessor, Max Payne 2 is also quite a fast-paced game. The guns introduced in the game have a good feel on them and while bullet time or shoot dodge is being used at the same time, it will double the enjoyment. Also, the enemies are not able to take ridiculous amount of bullets before they die anymore, which is a huge improvement on its own over the first Max Payne game. The gradually slowing bullet time is an awesome invention as it is easier for the player to handle big amount of opponents at the same time. The controllabilty of Max's moves is still going strong, the level of voice acting is great and because there is some improvements on the enemy AI, Max Payne 2 is a very enjoyable game at its best.

Now, not only the game mechanics has been proven to be better in Max Payne 2 than they are in Max Payne 1, but also the graphics have taken a big leap forward. Overall the environmental texturing have gotten to a higher level. Max can see his own reflection and the faces seen in the game are more natural than they used to be in the previous Max Payne game. The cars are a bit more than just boxes on the wheels and the whole level design is much more interesting.

Despite all the enhancements, the game is still all about running and shooting with no considerable variation between the firefights you encounter. The overall amount of usable guns is still quite low and the game will not last too long, as an average person who is playing the game through for the first time can beat the game in about 5 hours. Additional game modes seem to be quite useless to try as there is nothing to achieve by playing them. Also the original dark and gritty story has been swapped to a new and lame one, which is all about Max losing another loved one while also being betrayed by someone thought to be a friend of his. The dreams Max is experiencing while the story goes on have lost a big part of their original meaning as a source of dark and twisted feelings.

After all there is a huge amount of improvements in Max Payne 2, even though the run and shoot part leaves still much to be desired along with some other downsides seen in the game. Throughout the game you can find some easter eggs, and the mods made for this game can offer you a lot of additional fun. To this date I have beaten Max Payne 2 six times: three times before I had it on Steam and three times after that, with every given difficulty option. Because the game is quite short, I ended up spending only about 30 hours by playing it and could still give it a go. In other words I don't regret the time I have spent playing on this game. If you liked the predecessor of Max Payne 2, without a doubt you will fall in love with this one. The quality has been guaranteed, even though some things mentioned above could have been made better.

Max Payne 2: The Fall of Max Payne looks, plays, and feels like it's what the first entry in the series  would have been if they'd spent a few more years and a few more dollars on it. Detective Payne has traded his ridiculous, frozen smirk of the past game for a fully-rendered face with lips that actually move in the rare occurrence that he utters something out loud. The TV shows that can be watched on scattered TV sets have been similarly flesh out. Not only do they tell longer, more complete stories, but those stories tie into the game's plot thematically. Even the platforming elements that made the original Max Payne seem overall less professional have been toned down to the point of unobtrusiveness. And of course, there's still a full shooting gallery worth of mooks to mow down in bullet-time, all of which is still broken up by graphic novel-styled cutscenes. This sequel is simply a second helping of Payne with a few improvements thrown into the mix - almost a continuation. Loose ends left by its predecessor are tied up along the way and this distinct tale finishes up a little neater than the last. It feels like the punctuation on Max's story, and though more of this good thing would be welcome, it feels complete.

Introduction
Sequel to the the Max Payne franchise by the finnish company Remedy, published initially by 3D Realms and Rockstar, now just Rockstar North. Unfortunately it sold poorly despite it's brilliant innovations in noir-style story telling and overall improvement.

Gameplay
Gameplay remains mainly unchanged except that bullet time has been tweaked so that transitions in bullet time and reloading now seemlessly react, continuing the action and letting the player experience a full Hard Boiled scene of frantic gunfire and shootdodging!

Difficulty was judged via the AI, on all three difficult settings which give less bullet time - meaning you have to manage it or die very easily due to the high damage of bullets shot from enemies. Enemies also react much faster and take cover when injured.


Criticisms
Major
Massively stripped down difficulty from the first game which was reasonably difficult on it's own. I partially want to add that I played this on Dead on Arrival and found it far too easy even with the limited Bullet Time and increased damage from bullets and less regeneration from painkillers.

Weird criticism for sure but this is not a fault of Remedy's, it's a fault of Rockstar's getting their grubby hands on a franchise themselves published but developed in such a way that used their own version of writing which was far poorer than Sam Lakes, it also ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ized Max's character and removed every bit of the NOIR setting it initially had for a sleazy Brazil location. (which was intended for GTAIV, i.e R*AGE)

Minor
Far too much sub-weapon types that have a similar recoil pattern, compared to the original Max Payne, this makes the game rather easy to play.

Shotguns are incredibly weak in this game.

Gunplay
Gun-totting, fast, frantic slow-motion action, which puts a clear emphasis on using bullet time to see the bullets follow the path of your aim which grants you with scenes of grandiose violence and ragdolling hilarity and cinematic badassery.

Pistols are the starting equipment of Max Payne's arsenal - a weak overall firearm but ammo is frequent, rifles are mediocre in terms of damage but accurate and easily land headshots like no tommorow, explosives cover a wide radius but risk Max's health as well, sub-machine guns are balanced and damage wise but their rate of fire is far superior that the DPS (Damage Per Second) compensates for it.

Music
A transition from heavy mix of piano and double bass to many an noir orchestra mix of violins, harspicords (?) and the occassional electronica to tie it together.

Graphics
Characters model quality has improved majorly. Max and characters have vertex facial animation now and their animations look impressive (for the time). Shadowmapping ensures realistic lighting. Environment feels alive with criminal activies and the scale is larger than before.
